entry.title: [Extensions] Modernize messaging APIs in tests.
entry.content:
This CL modernizes usage of messaging APIs in test:



1. chrome.extension.onRequest -> chrome.runtime.onMessage

2. chrome.extension.sendRequest -> chrome.runtime.sendMessage

3. chrome.tabs.sendRequest -> chrome.tabs.sendMessage



Some call sites are left to ensure test coverage for MV2. A few

other remaining tests sites will be migrated in a follow-on CL.

entry.title: WebUI: Introduce new cr-ripple element, forked from paper-ripple.
entry.content:
cr-ripple differs from paper-ripple in the following ways:



1) Migrated from old "Polymer(...)" syntax to "extends PolymerElement".

2) Migrated from JS to TS.

3) Replaced usage of Polymer synthetic gesture (up/down) events

with native pointerup/pointerdown.

4) Replaced usage of IronA11yKeysBehavior with explicit event

listeners.

5) Replaced this.listen()/this.unlisten() helpers with EventTracker.

6) Removed usage of debounce(), since it does not seem needed.

7) Removed simulatedRipple() method, not used anywhere.



Added some initial tests for cr-ripple, and planning to add a few more

as a follow-up (previous paper-ripple implementation had no tests to

begin with).



cr-ripple will be hooked up to CrPaperRippleMixin and elsewhere in

follow-up CLs.



This is part of the larger effort to migrate paper-ripple (as

cr-ripple) to Lit.



Bug: 330377196

Change-Id: I62feb695d254b1833119902671b0b1fd5a5a903c

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5384321

Reviewed-by: John Lee

Commit-Queue: Demetrios Papadopoulos

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1276004}

entry.title: snap-group: Calculate snapped window bounds correctly in snap group
entry.content:
This cl did the following stuff:



1. Fixed the snapped bounds calculation in snap group creation.



2. Consolidated the snapped window bounds refresh in snap group.



3. Reduced unnecessary divider bounds updates.



4. Rename `split_view_divider_` in `SnapGroup` to be

`snap_group_divider_` to be more specific.



5. Improves the comments in `SnapGroup`.



Demo: http://b/329890139#comment2

Fixed: b/329890139

Test: Updated existing + manually

entry.content:
This CL removes RouterRegistrationMethod in service_worker.mojom. This

was used for the guard to avoid the misuse of the deprecated

RegisterRouter() and the new AddRoutes() methods.



RegisterRouter() related code was removed, so we don't need the

RouterRegistrationMethod enum anymore.

entry.title: MediaApp: Switch to geometry RectF in JS APIs and roll MediaApp package.
entry.content:

object generated by the Mojo code, so there is no longer any need for

entry.title: IME user data: JapaneseLegacyConfig to match source data structure.
entry.content:
Originally this proto matched how the "settings page" showed the

information. However, the settings page could change in the future but the internal config definition is likely to be static. The point of this API is not to convert existing config to the settings page equivalent, and if the mapping changes for some reason, we don't want it to become the responsibility of the FetchJapanaeseLegacyConfig call to convert this to a new settings page.



To make this a simple fetch with no conversions to the settings page options, we should make this proto match the config

as close as possible to avoid confusion.



Bug: b/328997239

Change-Id: I542c828033de027e943c014486c6f87ec53c4e34

entry.title: [A11y] Store DOMNodeIDs instead of AXIDs in AXRelationCache.
entry.content:
This helps prepare for downstream CLs that will disallow creation of

AXObjects in the middle of the tree in general, and then future removal

of code that repairs holes in the middle of the tree, because the holes

will no longer exist. AXObjects will always be created from the root

down, and subtrees will always be filled out.

entry.title: Cleanup media::KeySystemSupportObserver
entry.content:
- Rename KeySystemSupportObserver to KeySystemSupportRegistration

- Remove unnecessary virtual function

- Add clarifying comments.



TESTED:

* Add logs to see the size observer remote set in browser process.

(after this line

https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/media/key_system_support_impl.cc;drc=eb3c1d87f1c717de44fdaadb8b83041584f6a6b3;l=59)



The following is observed only when moving key systems to a per-frame

model. See

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5168850



* Visit integration.widevine.com/player

* Click play observer logs (observer_remotes_.size() = 1)

* Visit another site (e.g. shaka-player-demo.appspot.com) and play

encrypted media

* Check logs find (observer_remotes_.size() = 2)

* Close integration.widevine.com/player tab and ensure render process

for that tab is destroyed (e.g. in Task Manager)

* Visit integration.staging.widevine.com/player and click play

* Observer logs and find (observer_remotes_.size() = 2) whereas before

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5168850 the

logs would say (observer_remotes_.size() = 3)



Bug: b/321307544

entry.title: Reland "ChromeOS: Do not report previously discarded tabs to resourced"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit d3ed019ea2664906e5b0e9933b257729d0058c09



Reason for reland: This CL raced CQ with 2e188a74beec810b50b4af41b57859541901170b and was reverted after a build failure. The test code that caused the build failure has been fixed now.



Original change's description:

> ChromeOS: Do not report previously discarded tabs to resourced

>

> resourced uses the list of tab processes to calculate how much memory

> can be freed by killing tabs of a certain priority. When a tab has been

> discarded, it should not be included in this list even if its processes

> are still alive.

>

> Skip reporting discarded and marked tab processes to resourced.

>

> Change-Id: Ie384f4c3efe78af7301c9757c13ae749ea747862

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5363999

entry.title: Simplify arithmetic operations on calc-size() during animation.
entry.content:
This tries to ensure that math done by the animation code keeps

calc-size() at the top level of an expression rather than creating

arithmetic operations containing calc-size() expressions. This is a

step towards following the spec's rules that calc-size() cannot be

nested within calc() expressions. It also makes it easier for animation

code to examine calc-size() values since they are always at the top

level of the expression.



Bug: 313072

Change-Id: I37ca94bcf3c0897f83fa84ed56f367522dc5c5e7

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5374566

Reviewed-by: Daniil Sakhapov

Commit-Queue: David Baron

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1275978}

entry.title: PDF OCR: add a test exercising the batching in PDF OCR
entry.content:
Use a twenty-page PDF to test exercising the code for batching PDF OCR

requests thoroughly. Using this twenty-size PDF lets the test to use the

batch size = 2, which allows it to exercise merging more than one tree

update created by PDF OCR requests.



This CL also updates PDFOCRIntegrationTest to use expected output files.



Note that "twenty-page.in" was used to create the same name in PDF but

including accessible text. "inaccessible-text-in-twenty-page.pdf" was

then created by printing the accessible version as image.

entry.title: UsbServiceLinux: Only monitor usb udev events
entry.content:
UsbServiceLinux currently creates a UdevWatcher with no filter, which

means it receives every udev event. When an event arrives,

BlockingTaskRunnerHelper::OnDeviceAdded immediately discards any events

that don't come from the usb subsystem. Because the UdevWatcher

internal file watcher uses one-shot events, this causes it to be marked

inactive. crrev.com/c/5150583 adds a path that can cause the watcher to

then be stopped entirely, depending on exactly which USB devices are

present at boot.



By adding a subsystem=usb filter to the initial UdevWatcher, this avoids

the whole set of unwanted events and deactivate/reactivate/stop epoll

behavior. Since the handler already only processes events from the usb

subsystem, this should result in the exact same set of events being

handled.



Bug: 323765877

Bug: 328506585

Test: Boot Chromebook with no USB devices and attach after login



Change-Id: If1b38c9721a975a93653ce27bef7ea5fb367a30d

entry.title: Add a way make the background overlay non-transparent
entry.content:
... in viz debugger.



We are tracking down a bug that manifests in Lacros, where

the requested window bounds is slightly wider (generally 1px)

than the actual renderer content. This 1px difference causes

visual artifacts to users, particularly seen during a window

interactive resize operation.



For instance, when the bug manifests, the background overlay

is also 1px wider than the rendered content.

We are adding the toggle to viz_debugger as a way to easily/visually

verify the bug.



R=petermcneeley@chromium.org

entry.title: [codeql] Add additional logging to index_target.py.
entry.content:
We seem to have some compilation fail on the bots but succeed when run

locally.



Ordinarily this wouldn't be a big deal. In principle CodeQL should

ignore failed compilation commands and produce a workable database.



However, in practice, these failed commands seem to emit

improperly-formatted brotli streams that then fail to decode and seem to

cause issues with database creation.



For instance: https://logs.chromium.org/logs/chromium/buildbucket/cr-buildbucket/8755608384436359905/+/u/index_target.py/stdout

determine which commands are failing and why.

entry.title: [A11y] Use CachedPreviousSiblingIncludingIgnored()
entry.content:
Avoid potential infinite recursion when initializing a newly added

child, which may need the previous sibling in

ComputeIsUsedForLabelOrDescription() -> SupportsNameFromContents()

for a element with role="row".



This does not seem to occur now but it is hit in CL:5020124, where

we more eagerly build out subtrees.



The recursion occurs because PreviousSiblingIncludedIgnored()

will attempt to get the included parent's children, even recomputing

them, even if we're already in the middle of computing the children.

Fortunately we have a check for this kind of problematic recursion.



Bug: 324786153

Change-Id: Icaf137bda28c4da82877a22f5e9cffbeaa980a31

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5381479

entry.title: tests: Enable Gpu Testing on Ozone Wayland for GpuMemoryBufferImplTest
entry.content:
Currently, the GpuMemoryBufferImplTest for NativePixmap is a no-op,

because 1) It doesn't use a Gpu, 2) As default it use X11 as platform,

which `IsConfigurationSupportedForTest` will always returns false and

skip everything.



This patch needs the test to be ran with these flags:

`--ozone-platform=wayland` `--use-gpu-in-tests`, and probably should be

ran by a fyi.gpu runner. Because Wayland has a valid implementation

of `IsConfigurationSupportedForTest`. And the code will run into actual

code of creating and importing native pixmap handles. On X11 platform I

don't know how to implement `IsConfigurationSupportedForTest` yet, so we

can only now discover problems under Wayland (and possible other

platforms). Also, add error log when importing handles doesn't meet size

and format check.



By this patch, we can discover the problem encountered in

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5338184



I'm not quite familiar with configuring test bots, so I might need you

guide through.



Change-Id: Idb25430b10cf3465cdc47767fdbe6d59fe85c008

Cq-Include-Trybots: luci.chromium.try:gpu-fyi-try-lacros-amd-rel,gpu-fyi-try-lacros-intel-rel,gpu-fyi-try-linux-amd-rel,gpu-fyi-try-linux-intel-rel,gpu-fyi-try-linux-nvidia-rel,linux_optional_gpu_tests_rel

entry.title: Add [E-]AC-3 to CDM-supported codecs
entry.content:
Contrary to video streams, in the case of audio streams the CDM is not

responsible for decoding. It only decrypts the encoded data and hands it

over to one of the regular decoders. Thus, the codecs listed by

GetCdmSupportedAudioCodecs() should match the codecs supported by

//media.

entry.title: ozone/drm: Add UMAs to track test modeset status and fallback usage
entry.content:
Add two new UMAs to track the success rate of test modeset and the

extent of the fallback.



Ozone.Drm.TestOnlyModesetOutcome tracks the outcome of a test-only

modeset configuration request. The outcome is either SUCCESS,

FALLBACK_SUCCESS if the fallback eventually succeeded, or FAILURE for

test modeset failure for both with and without fallback.



Ozone.Drm.TestOnlyModesetFallbacksAttempted tracks the number of

fallback CRTC-connector configurations attempted in the fallback. The

count will only increment for attempted fallbacks, so if the fallback

ended prematurely due to a success, then not all permutations will be

reflected in the count.



Bug: b:327477395

Test: ozone_unittests && manual testing with chrome://histograms

entry.title: graphite: Split flush and submit
entry.content:
Move FlushSurface, SubmitIfNecessary, etc. to SharedContextState so they

can be used in both RasterDecoder and CopySharedImageHelper. Make it so

that FlushSurface flushes the Graphite recorder while SubmitIfNecessary

submits the Graphite context in preparation for possibly deferring the

submit if allowed by the shared image backing.



No functional changes are intended with this CL.



Bug: 328104159

entry.title: [libc++] Temporarily define individual ABI flags instead of _LIBCPP_ABI_VERSION for Fuchsia
entry.content:
With https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pull/74482, the unstable ABI

has been changed such that std::array::iterator and

std::string_view::iterator are no longer raw pointers. However, parts of the

Fuchsia SDK still rely on this behavior (fxbug.dev/328282937). To temporarily

unblock the roll, we explicitly set the individual ABI flags for Fuchsia so we

have all the unstable ABI features except for that change.



Bug: chromium:328308661

Change-Id: I2a43bc64b9cca9907363943410273332c83e7384

entry.title: oak birch: remove chip from context menu
entry.content:
This cl implements the functionality of removing a birch chip from

birch bar by selecting "Hide the Suggestion" on chip's context

menu.



Previously, we implemented this by delegating the removing chip

action to its birch bar. Since we need to remove the chips with

corresponding suggestion on other birch bars, we ask the birch

bar controller to remove the chips with selected suggestion from

all birch bars.



Demo is shown in the bug comment.



Unit tests will be added to a following cl.



Bug: b:329665146

entry.title: Birch: Add removal of BirchCalendarItems to BirchItemRemover
entry.content:
Add an event id to BirchCalendarItems for use by the BirchItemRemover.

Similar to BirchTabItems, BirchCalendarItems have their event id hashed

and stored in a persistent proto managed by BirchItemRemover. These

removed calendar events will be filtered out before items are used by

the UI.

entry.title: Demo Mode: Add more explanation to the metric DemoMode.DwellTime
entry.content:
DemoMode.DwellTime = 0 is actually an intentional behavior when there's

only one user action, e.g. pressing keyboard once. In this case,

first_user_activity_ = last_user_activity_ so DemoMode.DwellTime =

last_user_activity_ - first_user_activity_ = 0. Therefore, we add the

above scenario to the metric explanation to reduce the confusion.

entry.title: Add naive implementation of `beginWebGPUAccess`.
entry.content:
Explainer:

https://github.com/fserb/canvas2D/blob/master/spec/webgpu.md



This API converts a canvas' currently-displayed image to a

GPUTexture which can be used by WebGPU. At present, the current

implementation uses Snapshot(), which always clones the image.

An ideal design would avoid this copy, but this gives us a

starting point to iterate from.



We do not yet have any guards against continuing to use the

Canvas2D APIs after calling `beginWebGPUAccess`. This is safe

because we don't actually steal the existing texture away from

the canvas; it still has its own storage, distinct from the WebGPU

texture. Once `endWebGPUAccess` is implemented, it is expected

that this would clobber any canvas changes that might have

occurred during WebGPU access (as the canvas texture would be

replaced by the GPUTexture from WebGPU).



Change-Id: Ied046431fbfdfff673ae61280317f8e0931ece7e

Bug: 41490345

entry.title: [UIA] Set AutomationId property to "RootWebArea" for document node
entry.content:
As discussed in https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40065516#comment32,

Chromium was always setting the AutomationId to an empty string even

when no value was provided. While this respects the UIA documentation,

it was causing issues with the native UIA enablement for some

customers that were checking whether this value was set or not.



The UIA bridge was not doing the right thing by not setting it to an explicitly empty string when not provided, and customers started

relying on this bug as if it was a feature.



Instead of always settings an empty string as value, we now set the

document node's AutomationId to "RootWebArea". This should fix their

issue, while still respecting the documentation.



Bug: 40065516

entry.title: Prepare to convert SBThreatType to an enum class in /chrome/browser/apps/guest_view
entry.content:
It's somewhat difficult to log an SBThreatType as an UMA histogram since

we don't have a kMaxValue. We can't simply add a kMaxValue because

SBThreatType is an enum instead of enum class, and we'd be exposing a

constant safe_browsing::kMaxValue. This CL prepares to convert

SBThreatType to an enum class in /chrome/browser/apps/guest_view.



That requires two changes:



- SBThreatType is no longer implicitly convertible to int, so we will

need a few static casts



- SBThreatType values are now in the namespace

safe_browsing::SBThreatType instead of just safe_browsing. In some

places this is fixed by adding the new namespace, and in some places

with a "using enum" declaration. We can't just add a "using enum" for

all usages of SBThreatType because "using enum" would declare a

constant kMaxValue. So "using enum" is only used when many

SBThreatType constants are used, and in as narrow a scope as possible.



This CL was uploaded by git cl split.



Bug: 329698341

entry.title: Reland "[DIPS] Add ChromeDriver support for Bounce Tracking Mitigations"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit 37078af2fda407a920e73ab809cc3e0411e9a536



Most importantly, https://crrev.com/c/5374999/ fixed a race

condition that stopped Bounce Tracking Mitigations from classifying

bounces as stateful if cookie accesses by the bouncing site/page

were reported after the navigation to the landing page had already

started.



This CL improves upon the original by restructuring the python

integration test for the RunBounceTrackingMitigations command to use

distinct pages for each stage of the bounce flow, rather than reusing

the initial page. This ensures a stateful bounce actually occurs and

is recorded before the command is executed.



Additionally, the test is added to the browser specific filter for

chrome-headless-shell, since the python integration tests are now also

run against chrome-headless-shell and Bounce Tracking Mitigations is

implemented in //chrome.



Original change's description:

> [DIPS] Add ChromeDriver support for Bounce Tracking Mitigations

>

> This ChromeDriver command makes use of Chrome DevTools Protocol command

> added in crrev.com/c/4466867, to support

> chromestatus.com/feature/5171591763197952

>

> Spec PR: https://github.com/privacycg/nav-tracking-mitigations/pull/63
